item.label: Midbrain
item.name: Midbrain
item.description: The midbrain is AKA the mesencephalon. Within its parts (tectum, tegmentum, substantia nigra and cerebral crus or basis pedunculi), it contains cranial nerve nuclei, all of the clinically important ascending and descending tracts, etc. It is traversed by the cerebral aqueduct or aqueduct of Sylvius. It originates developmentally from the mesencephalon.

item.label: Cerebellum
item.name: Cerebellum
item.description: The cerebellum is sometimes referred to as the 'small' brain.  It is located within the posterior fossa, superior to the brain stem. It consists of a finely convoluted cortical surface of folia, a central core of white matter (AKA medullary center) and four paired deep nuclei (dentate, emboliform, fastigial and globose) embedded within the white matter core. The cerebellum functions in the planning and coordination of movement.

item.label: Anterior incisure
item.name: Anterior incisure
item.description: When viewed from the superior aspect of the cerebellum, the anterior indentation (between the cerebellar hemispheres and in line with the vermis) is the anterior incisure.

item.label: Anterior lobe
item.name: Anterior lobe
item.description: The anterior lobe of the cerebellum is that portion of the cerebellum anterior to the primary fissure, including parts of the vermis and hemisphere.

item.label: Primary fissure
item.name: Primary fissure
item.description: The primary fissure of the cerebellum separates the anterior lobe from the posterior lobe of the cerebellum. It extends into both the vermal and hemispheric aspects of the cerebellum.

item.label: Posterior lobe
item.name: Posterior lobe
item.description: The posterior lobe of the cerebellum is that portion between the primary and posterolateral fissures.  It includes parts of the vermis and hemispheres.

item.label: Posterior incisure
item.name: Posterior incisure
item.description: When viewed from the superior surface of the cerebellum, the posterior indentation (between the cerebellar hemispheres and in line with the vermis) is called the posterior incisure.

item.label: Cerebellum, functional zones
item.name: Cerebellar functional zones
item.description: The cerebellum is precisely organized in terms of cellular types and layers.  In addition to that precise organization, there is evidence to indicate that different areas of the cerebellum have different functions in terms of motor control and corrdination.  These different areas of the cerebellum are termed functional zones and are arranged in a longitudinal direction from the medially-located vermis to the laterally-located hemispheres.  The three paired zones are:  vermal, paravermal (or intermediate) and lateral.

item.label: Vermal zone
item.name: Vermal zone
item.description: The vermal zone of the cerebellum is involved with the regulation of posture and stereotyped movements such as walking.  Its major outputs project to the vestibular nuclei and the reticular formation both directly and via connections in the fastigial nuclei of the cerebellum.  These connections allow the cerebellum to influence lower motor neurons in the spinal cord via the vestibulospinal and reticulospinal tracts.

item.label: Paravermal zones
item.name: Paravermal zones
item.description: The paravermal zone of the cerebellum is also known as the intermediate zone since it is located between the vermal and lateral functional zones.  The major inputs to the paravermal zone are from the motor cerebral cortex (corticopontocerebellar tract) and the spinal cord (dorsal and ventral spinocerebellar plus cuneocerebellar tracts), while the major output from this area is via the interposed nucleus (globose + emboliform) to the red nucleus and back to the motor cortex via connections in the ventral lateral and ventral anterior thalamic nuclei.  Via these connections, the paravermal zone of the cerebellum influences lower motor neurons via the corticospinal tract and possibly the rubrospinal tract. The principal impact is on voluntary movements.

item.label: Lateral zones
item.name: Lateral zones
item.description: The lateral zone of the cerebellum makes up the largest part of the cerebellum and projects to the dentate nucleus.  It is thought to be involved in the planning and programming of learned, skilled movements movements, such as playing the piano or typing.  Since it is part of a major neural circuit with the motor and premotor cerebral cortex [motor/premotor cortex to corticopontocerebellar tract to contralateral cerebellar cortex to dentate nucleus to contralateral ventral lateral and ventral anterior thalamus and back to motor/premotor cerebral cortex] it is thought that it may act by influencing the motor and premotor cortex.
